newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Indonesia sees possibility of new refinery.
newsitem.headline: Indonesia sees possibility of new refinery.

text.p: Indonesian Mines and Energy Minister Ida Bagus Sudjana said on Wednesday it was possible state oil company Pertamina would build a new refinery.

"We are looking at the possibility of building a new refinery. There is possibility Pertamina will build a new refinery. Pertamina has asked (the government) for a new refinery," Sudjana told Reuters.
Pertamina president director Faisal Abda'oe told Reuters in January that Indonesia needed two more refineries by 2000 to meet burgeoning domestic demand for fuel products.
He said the refineries should each have a capacity of 125,000 barrels per day (bpd) to help demand in Indonesia, Asia's only member of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC).
Sudjana said on Wednesday at a ceremony on safety in refineries that domestic fuel consumption was growing around an average of six percent annually.
"To anticipate an annual growth of six percent in fuel consumption, the capacity of refineries needs to be increased and this needs major investment," Sudjana said.
Pertamina now has eight refineries with a combined capacity of 989,500 bpd. There are no private refineries.
Pertamina has said it would import about 10 million kilolitres of fuel products in fiscal 1997/98 (April-March), up from an estimated seven million kilolitres in 1996/97.

Pertamina said domestic fuel product consumption was estimated at 50.9 million kilolitres in 1997/98, compared with 47.6 million kilolitres in 1996/97. While fuel production is around 40.9 million kilolitres.
